Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Welcome to the forum. Another question that comes to mind is whether you have ever been told you have an enlarged prostate? This is usually harmless, but can also trend the PSA upward a bit. Hello highlander, I have been told that I have a prostate that is larger than normal for my age by both my GP and the urologist post DRE. I haven't been officially diagnosed with BPH
Posts.Title: PSA Questions

Posts.Content: Just wanted to say thank you to everyone who responded to my post. It's really a good feeling to have a place to go to where people are so helpful. I think I will get another PSA test in 3 months to see where things stand. I'll also see if I can get a free PSA test - might as well get a baseline. I've heard of a couple of other tests: PHI - which I've heard is valid for PSA results of over 4.0? I've also heard of the PCa3 test. Has anyone heard of or had experience with these tests? Also what are is the general feeling about getting my prostate density calculated? Oh the humourous front: I bet with all my focus on my prostate, per Mr Murphy, I'll get taken out by something completely unrelated! If that is the case I will have as my epitaph: "It wasn't prostate cancer"
Posts.Title: PSA Questions

Posts.Content: Hello everyone, This is my first post to the forum. A little background I'm a 50 year old male whose father was diagnosed at age 56 with PCa due to an irregular DRE. He had RP; however the cancer had spread beyond the prostate to the surrounding tissues (though lymph nodes were clear). Aside from extensive side effects from the RP he was symptom free for about 10 or so years but ultimately succumbed to the disease at age 72. I started having my PSA take at age 41 (2006). I have included the results below in order that I can frame my question: Oct '06 - 1.31 - Unknown machine/assay Oct '07 - 1.84 - Unknown machine/assay Oct '08 - 1.60 - Dade Behring EIA method (Hybritech) Feb '09 - NO TEST Feb '10 - 1.74 - Dade Behring EIA method (Hybritech) Jan '11 - 1.85 - Dade Behring EIA method (Hybritech) Jan '12 - 1.88 - Siemens Healthcare Diagnostics EIA (Hybritech)* Feb '13 - 1.44 (1.77)** - Siemens/Centaur (WHO) Feb '14 - 1.78 - Siemens Healthcare Diagnostics EIA (Hybritech) Feb '15 - 2.28*** - Siemens Healthcare Diagnostics EIA (Hybritech) Mar '15 - 1.39 (1.71)** - Siemens/Centaur (WHO) Feb '16 - 1.68 (2.07)**/# - Siemens/Centaur (WHO) Mar '16 - 2.40 - Roche ECLIA (assay unknown) * Siemens bought Dade Behring and this is the same type of machine ** Adjusted value as the Siemens Centaur uses the WHO assay which records a 23% lower value than Hybritech. *** Prostitis symptoms. Placed on antibiotics # - Again had mild urethritis/prostitis symptoms. All tests negative. Referred to urologist. As you can see, I started off with a PSA above the mean. Given my family history, this has always elevated my concern. In general my PSA has hovered around 1.6 - 1.8. However, my last two tests within a couple months of each other are showing a rise in my PSA. Specifically the one from this February which was at an adjusted value of 2.07 and the other about four weeks later at 2.40. Last year I had prostatis symptoms prior to my PSA test, and sure enough my test was elevated. The doctor put me on antibiotics and I was retested again several weeks later at which point my PSA had lowered somewhat. This year I also had mild urethritis symptoms prior to my PSA test (lighting strikes again?) and was referred to a urologist since the cultures my primary performed returned negative. The urologist said that it is not uncommon to see mild cases of non-specific urethritis and it should resolve which it did between the Feb and March tests of this year. I should note that the March test performed by new GP at a new facility I am feeling quite alarmed since I saw effectively a 0.36 rise in my PSA from Feb 15 to Feb 16, and another 0.33 rise in less than month from Feb to March of this year. I will admit that I am paranoid about PCa since I watched my dad suffer and ultimately die from it as well my PSA has always seemed elevated (though both my GP and the urologist told me that I have a larger than normal prostate for my age which may account for it?) My question is that should I at this point push for a biopsy?
Posts.Title: PSA Questions

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Welcome to the forum. Another question that comes to mind is whether you have ever been told you have an enlarged prostate? This is usually harmless, but can also trend the PSA upward a bit. Hello highlander, I have been told that I have a prostate that is larger than normal for my age by both my GP and the urologist post DRE. I haven't been officially diagnosed with BPH
